history.content: I think you'll be absolutely fine, as I heard that math 110 in fact reteaches you much of the information.

children.subject: Would you say that 110 builds linear algebra from the ground up? Asking because I took 16AB but am shaky on the linear algebra content, and a lot of people have recommended 110 as a good class to take to build intuition for linear algebra.

hmmm I wouldn't necessarily say the ground up, because I found some parts of 110 easier when I already had some basic stuff down like how to multiply matrices and how to compute an inverse, so I wouldn't have to worry about computational basics and just focused on learning the proof based concepts that I was lacking (prior to 110 i wasn't very good at the kind of abstract proof based work of upper division courses like "Prove det(PAP^-1) = det(A) if P is invertible matrix". 

I do think the difficulty builds nicely in 110 - the first 3rd is a lot of review of 54 stuff, even such I was a teeny bit bored, but after the 1st midterm it started to ramp up into more heavy conceptual content that wasn't covered in 54. 

I definitely felt that 110 really developed my intuition for linear algebra, because I find following linear algebra problems in 127 and 189 this semester easier. (tho take that with a small grain of salt because I LOVE linear algebra so it might be just my affinity). 

If you've taken both 16a/b, even if you feel a little shaky, I think thats enough preparation because at least you have seen the topics beforehand, and can then focus on building the concepts you were shaky on the first time. Caveat: haven't taken 16a/b but based on what I've heard (and the fact that 16a/b is enough of a prereq for the lin alg in ee127) you should be fine, as long as you commit to keeping up with the material. Don't fall behind, because everything builds on each other. 

If you take it and the structure was like my semester, where the hw weren't due, definitely be sure to attempt all homework problems - the concepts built in problems were heavily used throughout the semester. And if you can't figure a problem out, make sure you understand the solutions.

Can confirm, the first third of 110 was going over a lot of 54 stuff, and then after the 1st midterm was when you got into non-54 stuff. 

Just make sure to keep up with the lectures, and reference online notes for anything you feel shaky on. 

I took 54 Fa17 and then 110 Fa18 and then felt fine.

history.content:
Hi, 

I was planning on taking Math 110 next semester, but I had last taken 54 spring three semesters ago. How prepared will I be? I heard that Math 110 reteaches a lot of the concepts from 54, but I'm still worried since it's been so long since I saw the material. For reference, I got an A- in 54, but felt a little shaky on some of the concepts.

Thanks!
history.subject: 110 3 semesters after 54
